questions.text: What is the JEP 378 that was targeted to Java 15?

options.text: ZGC: A Scalable Low-Latency Garbage Collector
options.explanation: ZGC was initially introduced in Java 11, not Java 15.
JEP 378, targeted for Java 15, introduces text blocks which allow for multi-line string literals that avoid the need for most escape sequences.
Although enhanced in Java 15, pattern matching for instanceof was initially introduced in Java 14 as a preview feature.
Records were introduced as a preview feature in Java 14 and finalized in later versions.

questions.text: Which JEP introduces the Sealed Classes as a preview feature in Java 15?

options.explanation: JEP 360 introduces Sealed Classes as a preview feature in Java 15, allowing class authors to control which other classes or interfaces may extend or implement them.
JEP 359 is for Records, introduced before Java 15.
JEP 384 deals with Records, but in the second preview not the introduction of Sealed Classes.
JEP 375 pertains to the second preview of Pattern Matching for instanceof, not Sealed Classes.

questions.text: What is the purpose of JEP 384 in Java 15?

options.explanation: Records were introduced in Java 14 as a preview feature.

options.text: To refine the Z Garbage Collector
options.explanation: JEP 384 does not deal with garbage collection improvements.

options.text: To provide the second preview of Records
options.explanation: JEP 384 refines the record class feature introduced in Java 14, providing a second preview in Java 15.
Text blocks were introduced as JEP 378, not JEP 384.

questions.text: Which feature introduced in Java 15 helps improve the performance of hidden classes?

options.explanation: JEP 339 introduces a new digital signature algorithm, not related to class performance.

JEP 371 introduces hidden classes, which are classes that cannot be used directly by the bytecode of other classes. They are intended for use by frameworks which generate classes at runtime and use them indirectly via reflection.

options.text: JEP 377: ZGC: A Scalable Low-Latency Garbage Collector
options.explanation: JEP 377 deals with garbage collection improvements.
JEP 378 introduces text blocks for easier string formatting, not class performance enhancements.

questions.text: What significant change does JEP 375 make in Java 15?

options.explanation: Records were introduced earlier in Java 14.
Sealed classes were introduced in Java 15 but under JEP 360.

options.text: Second preview of pattern matching for instanceof
options.explanation: JEP 375 provides the second preview of pattern matching for instanceof, improving type checking and casting.

options.text: Enhancements to the Z Garbage Collector
options.explanation: While ZGC was enhanced in Java 15, this was covered under JEP 377.

questions.text: Which JEP in Java 15 deals with cryptographic signatures?

options.explanation: JEP 339 introduces support for the Edwards-Curve Digital Signature Algorithm, which is a modern cryptographic algorithm.
JEP 381 is related to C++ language features in the JVM implementation, not cryptographic signatures.
JEP 375 enhances instanceof with pattern matching, unrelated to cryptography.
JEP 360 introduces sealed classes, which have no relation to cryptographic signatures.
